cards.front: What are Newton's laws of motion?
cards.back: Newton's first law states that an object at rest stays at rest, and an object in motion stays in motion with the same speed and direction unless acted upon by a force. Newton's second law states that the acceleration of an object is directly proportional to the net force acting on it and inversely proportional to its mass. Newton's third law states that for every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction.

questions.stem: What is the third Newton's law of motion?
options: Every action has an equal and opposite reaction.
An object at rest stays at rest if unforced.
Gravity acts only on objects in motion.
The total momentum of a closed system remains constant.
questions.rationale: Every action has an equal and opposite reaction is the third law of Newton's laws of motion.

insights.title: Newton's Laws of Motion Insight
insights.takeaway: Newton's First Law (Law of Inertia) states that an object at rest tends to stay at rest, and an object in motion tends to stay in motion with the same speed and direction unless acted upon by an external force. Newton's Second Law (F=ma) describes the relationship between an object's acceleration, mass, and the net force acting on it. Newton's Third Law (Action-Reaction Law) states that for every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction.

cards.back: Newton's First Law (Law of Inertia) states that an object at rest stays at rest and an object in motion stays in motion with the same speed and direction unless acted upon by a net force.

Newton's Second Law (F=ma) states that the acceleration of an object is directly proportional to the net force acting on it and inversely proportional to its mass. The formula is F = ma, where F is net force, m is the mass of the object, and a is its acceleration.

Newton's Third Law (Action-Reaction Law) states that for every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction. This means that whenever one object exerts a force on another, the second object exerts an equal and opposite force back on the first.

insights.title: First Law of Motion
insights.takeaway: An object at rest tends to stay at rest, and an object in motion tends to stay in motion with the same speed and direction unless acted upon by a net force.

insights.title: Second Law of Motion
insights.takeaway: The acceleration of an object is directly proportional to the net force acting on it and inversely proportional to its mass. This is expressed by the equation F = ma.

insights.title: Third Law of Motion
insights.takeaway: For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction. Essentially, when one object exerts a force on another, the second object exerts an equal and opposite force back on the first.

cards.back: 1) An object at rest stays at rest and an object in motion stays in motion with the same speed and direction unless acted upon by a net force. 2) The acceleration of an object is directly proportional to the net force acting on it and inversely proportional to its mass. 3) For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction.

questions.rationale: The third law of Newton's laws of motion is also known as the Law of Action and Reaction.

insights.title: Newton's Laws of Motion Insight
insights.takeaway: The three laws of motion describe the relationship between a body and the forces acting upon it, and how they affect its acceleration. The first law (inertia) states that an object in motion tends to stay in motion, while an object at rest tends to remain at rest unless acted upon by an external force. The second law (force equals mass times acceleration) explains that the acceleration of an object is directly proportional to the net force acting on it and inversely proportional to its mass. The third law (action-reaction) states that for every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction.
